docs.lead_paragraph: American Airlines has pulled back from the brink. Now all it has to do is figure out how to stay on top of the brutally competitive airline industry. In the year since it skirted bankruptcy, American, the nation's largest airline, and a unit of AMR, has wrung $2 billion in concessions from its unions and surprised Wall Street by cutting its costs to 9.5 cents a seat-mile in the fourth quarter.

headline.main: No Longer On the Brink, American Air Is Still in Peril

docs.abstract: American Airlines is long way from profitability despite gaining $2 billion in concessions from its unions and cutting its costs to 9.5 cents a seat-mile in fourth quarter; is also saddled with $21 billion debt, as well as ballooning pension and health care costs that it has few options to address; chief executive Gerard J Arpey comments; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Bomb Explodes in Baghdad As War Anniversary Nears A powerful car bomb exploded in central Baghdad, destroying the five-story Mount Lebanon hotel, killing at least 27 people and wounding 41. Iraqi rescue teams continued to search the rubble for survivors. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: ''IT'S been a dream for me,'' Tristana Waltz said of the four-foot-wide medicine chest in her new master bathroom in Manhattan, where she keeps her Kiehl's facial scrub, bath salts, hair dryer and battery of vitamins, medications and painkillers. In the guest bath she keeps another medicine cabinet, this one for her husband, Grier Eliasek, who uses it to hide his electric shaver, toothbrush and CD player.
docs.abstract: Supersizing of medicine cabinets in some new bathrooms described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed four abortion bills on Monday and yesterday. They would classify the death of a fetus as a murder unless it was induced by the mother or a medical professional she approved; require doctors to report physical or psychiatric complications that they believe are a ''primary, secondary or tertiary result'' of abortions to the State Department of Health; protect health care providers and insurance companies who refuse to participate in abortions; and make it a felony to intentionally allow the death of a viable fetus delivered in a failed abortion. The bills now go to the Senate. Ariel Hart (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Abortion Bills Pass

docs.abstract: Mississippi House passes four bills that grant new legal status to fetus and protect health care providers and insurers who refuse to participate in abortions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a law yesterday that would provide health insurance for many surviving spouses, domestic partners and children of uniformed correction officers and sanitation employees who die as a result of accident or injury. Only workers killed in the line of duty from Nov. 1, 1996, to Jan. 27, 2004, qualify under the new law. The legislation was introduced in response to the deaths of the Sanitation Department's district superintendent, Michael Gennardo, who was fatally shot by an unknown assailant in August 2001. In January of this year, another sanitation worker, Eva Barrientos, was killed while operating a front-loading EZ Pak collection truck. Jennifer E. Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Care For City Workers' Families

byline.original: By Jennifer E. Steinhauer (NYT); Compiled by Ian Urbina

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislators in the General Assembly are set to vote today on a legislative remedy to hold down escalating medical malpractice insurance costs that have prompted some doctors to threaten to leave New Jersey. The bill has stalled in the Assembly for a year, but lawmakers have tweaked it and say it will now provide financial help to doctors while maintaining the legal rights of malpractice victims. ''The bottom line is, doctors will get the relief they deserve and patients will get the care they need,'' said Assemblyman Joseph Roberts, the Democratic majority leader and a sponsor of the bill. The bill sets up a $90 million fund that would help doctors and hospitals pay insurance premiums for the next three years. The fund would be paid for by a $50-a-year license fee for doctors, lawyers, chiropractors and dentists and a new employers' tax of $3 for each worker for unemployment insurance. The bill tightens rules on filing lawsuits, though it does not put limits on awards, and gives state regulators the ability to scale back insurance rates that climb too quickly. The measure also sets stricter guidelines for filing malpractice lawsuits and gives judges more leeway to control verdicts.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Lawmakers To Vote On Malpractice Bill

docs.abstract: Legislators in New Jersey General Assembly will vote on bill that sets up $90 million fund to help doctors and hospitals pay malpractice insurance premiums for next three years; fund would be paid for by $50-a-year licence fee for doctors, lawyers, chiropractors and dentists; aim is to hold down escalating medical malpractice insurance costs that have prompted some doctors to threaten to leave state (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Republican business owner here in this November battleground state and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had the same questions Sunday for Senator John Kerry: Which foreign leaders told you they support your campaign, and when did you meet with them? The questions, in a volatile exchange at a forum here and in an interview on Fox News Sunday, stemmed from a comment that Mr. Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, made last Monday at a Florida fund-raiser. It was the second time in recent days that stray comments by Mr. Kerry diverted attention from his themes of creating jobs and providing health insurance.

headline.main: Kerry Remark on Foreign Leaders Faulted

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry, speaking in Bethlehem, Pa, is called upon by small businessman Cedric Brown to clarify remark about having support of foreign leaders; question relates to speech Kerry made at Florida fund-raiser; Kerry responds by saying America is meeting with new level of hostility in world because of Bush administration foreign policies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To Phebe M. Palin, giving birth with a doctor would have involved too many machines, too many drugs and, most likely, too many men. She had her daughter, Ava, with a midwife at a birthing center, and when she became pregnant again, she planned to repeat the experience. But about three months before her son, Yanai, was born last Dec. 24, the center, the Elizabeth Seton Childbearing Center in Greenwich Village, shut its doors, driven out of business by rising medical malpractice insurance premiums. Still determined to use a midwife and avoid a hospital, Ms. Palin, 33, delivered her baby at home, but found that her health insurance policy forced her to pay more for her choices.

headline.main: Use of Midwives, a Childbirth Phenomenon, Fades in City

docs.abstract: Use of midwives is declining in New York City and around nation; face fast-rising malpractice insurance premiums are cited as cause, as well as new limitations imposed on their practices by many hospitals and health insurance companies; this comes after 20 years of rapid growth in field; in 1998, certified nurse-midwives attended 7 percent of births nationally, but that figure has been going down since then; in New York City, where midwifery took hold more strongly than in most parts of country, certified nurse-midwives attended 9.7 percent of births in 2002, down from 12.2 percent in 1997; photos; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Spanish Voters' Anger Spurs Opposition Victory Spain's opposition Socialists swept to an upset victory in general elections, ousting the center-right party of Prime Minister José Maria Aznar in a groundswell of voter anger and grief over the handling of terrorist attacks in Madrid. Many voters suspected Al Qaeda plotted the attacks to punish Mr. Aznar for supporting the war in Iraq. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a study recently showing that the required addition of the vitamin folate, or folic acid, to wheat flour products appears to have greatly reduced the chance of dying from heart disease and stroke. Another recent study, comparing cholesterol-reducing drugs, found that heavy doses of Lipitor significantly reduce the risk of dying from heart disease (front page, March 9).

headline.main: The Search for a Healthier Heart

docs.abstract: Raymond J Rostan letter on March 9 article on cholesterol-reducing drugs; suggests less emphasis on treatment for heart disease and more on using folic acid as preventive
